data.title: Obituaries

data.text: Edna M. Appleby, Holland Resident Edna M. Appleby, a longtime Holland resident who was born and raised in East Aurora, died of respiratory failure Sept. 7, 2004 at Mercy Hospital in Buffalo. She was 83. Born Edna M. Kruse on Oct. 21, 1920, Mrs. Appleby was a graduate of East Aurora High School. In the 1940s, she was a waitress at Charlie’s Diner in East Aurora, and for many years did housecleaning and babysitting. She was a past president of the American Legion Auxiliary-Brink Post #607 and a member of Holland United Methodist Church, Holland Senior Citizens, and Fall Brook Rebekah Lodge. She was also a Red Cross Bloodmobile worker. Prior to moving to The Waters of Orchard Park, Mrs. Appleby loved to play cards, make candy, bowl and take care of her grandchildren. In her younger years, she enjoyed roller-skating at Creekside. Her husband, Arthur L. Appleby, died in October, 1968. Mrs. Appleby is survived by a daughter, Linda M. Smith of Holland; one brother, Earl Kruse of Chaffee; three grandchildren; and two great-grandchildren. In addition to her husband, she was pre-deceased by four sisters and four brothers. A funeral service was held Fri., Sept. 10 at Holland United Methodist Church, with interment at Holland Cemetery. Arrangements were handled by Wood Funeral Home, East Aurora. Imogene Frasher, 86 Imogene (Hinsch) Frasher, 86, formerly of Rolla, Mo., died Thursday morning, Sept. 9, 2004 at RiverWoods in Pennsylvania, where she lived for 20 years. She was born April 26, 1918, in Rock Island, Ill., the only child of the late Van Buren and Ethel (Bowman) Sally Hinsch. She was preceded in death by one daughter, Molly and her husband, William H. Frasher, a former sales executive at Fort Howard Paper Co. for more than 30 years and vice president of industry relations for Marcel Paper Co. for 15 years. Mr. Frasher died in January 2003 after 63 years of marriage. As a young woman in Rolla, Mrs. Frasher was a proud member of the Rainbow Girls. She was class valedictorian, graduating from Rolla High School in 1935 after achieving the highest score on the Latin exam in the state of Missouri. She went on to earn her bachelor of arts in 1939 in textiles and design from Lindenwood College, St. Charles, Mo. Mrs. Frasher was a loving wife, devoted mother and accomplished amateur artist and seamstress. She is survived by her children, Michael Frasher of Ridgefield, Conn., Kathleen Frasher of Pacific Palisades, Calif., Sara Frasher of Des Moines, Iowa, and Laurie Aburdene and her husband, Maurice, of Lewisburg, Pa.; and two grandchildren, Leila Zengel and her husband John of State College, Pa., and Joseph Aburdene of Los Angeles. A graveside service was conducted Sat., Sept. 11, in Hillside Cemetery, Fairfield County, Wilton, Conn. If friends should so desire, contributions in her memory may be made to RiverWoods, 3201 River Road, Lewisburg, PA 17837; Evangelical Hospice, 1 Hospital Drive Lewisburg, PA 17837; or the American Cancer Society, 1948 E. Third St., Williamsport, PA 17701. Gary H. Cronrath Funeral Home, South Second and St. Louis streets, Lewisburg, Pa., assisted the family with funeral arrangements. Robert Schuyler Lesher, Jr., “Schuy” Robert Schuyler Lesher, Jr., an East Aurora native who lived with his family in Washington, D.C., passed away at his home Aug. 23, 2004, after a battle with cancer. He was 60. Mr. Lesher was born at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, D.C., on Jan. 10, 1944 to Marjorie (Griffin) Lesher and the late Robert S. Lesher, Sr. while his father was in the military. Following the end of World War II, the family relocated to East Aurora. Known to his family and friends as “Schuy,” Mr. Lesher spent his childhood in East Aurora, graduating from East Aurora High School in 1961 and Bowdoin College in 1965. He was a lieutenant in the U. S. Navy and earned his MBA at Columbia University. A certified public accountant, Mr. Lesher was a partner at the accounting firm of KPMG Peat Marwick in New York City and Boston, later serving as the first Director of Federal Financial Systems at the U.S. Office of Management and Budget (OMB) and as Deputy Chief Financial officer at the U.S. Department of the Interior. His leadership and achievements were recognized by several Presidential Awards. He will always be loved and missed by those left behind, including his wife of 20 years, Joanne Freund Lesher of Washington, D.C.; two children, Rebecca, age 11, and Robert, age 4, both at home; his mother, Marjorie Lesher of East Aurora; two brothers, John Griffin (Linda) Lesher of Washington and Charles Edward (Gry) Lesher of Davis, Calif.; a sister, Kathryn (Lawrence) Davis of East Aurora; one niece, Carrie Davis; four nephews, Matt and Jordan Davis and Nick and Justin Lesher; and many friends and fellow workers. Burial was at Oakwood Cemetery in East Aurora during private family services on Mon., Aug. 30. A memorial service will be held at a later date at the National Presbyterian Church in Washington. If desired, the family would be grateful for memorial contributions in Mr. Lesher’s name to the Christian Children’s Fund or the American Cancer Society. Anthony Litterio, Formerly of South Wales Anthony Litterio of Orlando, Fla., who lived for many years in South Wales, died Aug. 13, 2004, after a short illness. He was 79. Born in Buffalo Feb. 16, 1925 to Mariano and Delicia Litterio, Mr. Litterio was a veteran of World War II, serving as a U.S. Navy boatswain mate. Later, Mr. Litterio became a machinist at General Motors Chevrolet plant on Delevan Avenue in Buffalo, where he worked for 30 years. He retired in 1978. Mr. Litterio was a devoted member of the South Wales Volunteer Fire Company and loved tending his small herd of Angus cows. In 1986, he and his wife of 50 years, Theresa, moved to Florida to enjoy their retirement. He is survived by his wife, Theresa G. (Sallie); a daughter, Tina (Michael) Kumiega of Ocoee, Fla.; a son, Martin (Lee Ann) of Holland; two grandchildren, Allison Marie Joyce and Anthony Mariano; a sister, Mary (Frank) Castiglia; a brother, Frank; and nieces, nephews and cousins. He was predeceased by two brothers, Dominic and Carl, and his sister, Teresa Murena. Friends are invited to attend a Mass of Christian Burial on Sat., Sept. 25, 11 a.m. at St. Joseph’s RC Church on Main Street in Holland. Graveside services at South Wales Cemetery on Olean Road will immediately follow. Marilyn M. Long, Jubilee Baker Marilyn M. Long of East Aurora died suddenly Sept. 6, 2004 at Mercy Hospital in Buffalo. She was 59. Born in Buffalo on April 11, 1945 to the late John and Margaret Benson Luther, the former Marilyn Luther married Rodney A. Long in 1966. She was employed as a baker at Jubilee Market in East Aurora since 1999. She also loved to garden. In addition to her husband, Mrs. Long is survived by two sons, David A. Long of Florida and Timothy A. Long of East Aurora; two brothers, David (Beth) Luther of Orlando, Fla., and Ronald (Ruby) Luther of Montgomery, Ala.; and nieces and nephews. Funeral services at Wood Funeral Home in East Aurora were private. Interment was at Woodlawn Cemetery, Orchard Park. Mary S. Nuwer, Cafeteria Worker Mary S. Nuwer, a cafeteria worker for many years in East Aurora High School, died Sept. 5, 2004 at her son’s home in East Aurora. She was 84. Born Mary Keem in the Town of Wales to the late Frank J. and the late Cecilia Glaser Keem on Sept. 29, 1919, Mrs. Nuwer was married in 1943 to her husband of 40 years, Myron. Mr. Nuwer died in 1983. The couple lived in the Wales and East Aurora area, where they built homes and raised their two children. She is survived by her son, William M., and her daughter, Susanne M. (Edward) Wolff, both of East Aurora; and three grandchildren, Cindy and Michael Wolff and Scott Nuwer. In addition to her husband and her parents, Mrs. Nuwer was predeceased by two brothers, Francis and Raymond. A funeral service was held at Wood Funeral Home in East Aurora, followed by interment in Evergreen Cemetery, Wales Center. Lillian Smith, Fisher-Price Retiree Lillian Curtis Smith, a longtime resident of West Falls who had moved to Cheektowaga in recent years, died suddenly on Aug. 28, 2004 at St. Joseph’s Hospital in Cheektowaga from injuries sustained in an automobile accident earlier that day. She was 75. Born in Orchard Park on July 7, 1929, Mrs. Smith was a graduate of Lancaster Central High School. She was employed as an assembler at Fisher-Price Toys for 22 years, retiring in 1990. She later worked at Mighty Taco and McDonalds restaurants in Cheektowaga. She was a member of St. Paul’s Lutheran Church in West Falls, and she also enjoyed flower arranging, crafts, bingo, bowling and traveling. Her husband, Glenn E. Smith, died in 1980. Mrs. Smith is survived by a daughter, Joan Srock of Depew; three sons, Roy A. Smith of Gales Creek, Ore., Gary E. Smith of West Falls, and Brian G. Smith of East Aurora; a sister, Dorothy Zilliox of Springbrook; eight grandchildren; and seven great-grandchildren. Funeral services were held at St. Paul’s Lutheran Church in West Falls on Sept. 4. Burial was in Griffins Mills Cemetery. Arrangements were made by Wood Funeral Home, East Aurora. Lawrence D. Murray, Holland Resident Lawrence D. Murray, a Holland resident who once owned an East Aurora sporting goods store, died Tues., Aug. 31, at The Waters of East Aurora. He was 76. Born in West Seneca on Sept. 5, 1928 to Raymond and Bernice Murray, he married the former Dawn Lingeman on Aug. 15, 1981. Mr. Murray was in management at Ford Motor Company in Woodlawn for many years. He also owned and operated The Tackle Box, a sporting goods store in East Aurora, for ten years. He was an avid fisherman and enjoyed model railroading. He was a member of the Hunter’s Creek Bible Baptist Church in Holland. He is survived by his wife of 23 years, Dawn; two sons, Daniel (Elaine) Murray of Java and David Murray of Springville; four daughters, Margaret (John) Litwin of Cheektowaga, Lisa Keysaw of Pennsylvania, Kathleen (Ron) Morlock of Centerville, and Susan (Timothy) Michaels of Otto; 15 grandchildren; and seven great-grandchildren. Two brothers, Ray and Jack Murray; a granddaughter, Melissa Morlock; and a stepson, Scott W. Clarke, preceded Mr. Murray in death. Funeral services were held Fri., Sept. 3, at Kenneth Howe Funeral Home in East Aurora. If desired, memorials may be made to the Hunter’s Creek Bible Baptist Church Building Fund. W. Paul Steinwachs, Active Volunteer W. Paul Steinwachs, a computer and tax specialist who volunteered countless hours in the East Aurora community, died Fri., Sept. 10, 2004 in Roswell Park Cancer Institute after a brief illness. He was 73. Born in Buffalo on April 13, 1931 to Alphonse and Anastasia (McGee) Steinwachs, Mr. Steinwachs graduated from St. Joseph’s Collegiate Institute, later in life graduating with honors from Erie Community College. As a sergeant he was stationed at Elmandorf Air Force Base in Anchorage, Alaska; he also served in the Korean War. He and his wife, the former Diane Carlin of Buffalo, were married on Sept. 13, 1952. They moved to East Aurora in 1962, Mrs. Steinwachs says, because they felt the community would be a great place to raise their seven children. Mr. Steinwachs worked at Sperry-Univac as a computer field engineer from 1959 to 1986, and at Fisher-Price Toys as a personal computer maintenance manager from 1987 to 1996. After earning his associates degree in business, he worked as a tax preparation specialist with H&R Block from 1999 to 2001. He was an active parishioner at Immaculate Conception RC Church in East Aurora and a member of the Knights of Columbus. His other volunteer efforts included membership in the East Aurora chapter of the St. Vincent de Paul society, where he served as president for many years; as an AARP tax collector; and as head of the East Aurora Center for Volunteer Income Tax Assistance (VITA). In addition to his beloved wife, survivors include four daughters, Donna Steinwachs of Buffalo, Julie (Dean) Long of East Aurora, Mary (Louis) Miller of Bethany, and Melissa Steinwachs of Snyder; three sons, Michael (Susan) of East Aurora, Lawrence (Mary Louise) of Rochester, and William (Michele) of East Aurora; a brother, James Steinwachs of Buffalo; and 13 grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial was offered Wed., Sept. 15, at Immaculate Conception RC Church. Burial was in Oakwood Cemetery, East Aurora. Arrangements were handled by Wood Funeral Home, East Aurora. If desired, the family suggests memorial contributions in Mr. Steinwachs’ name be made to a charity of your choice.
